newsitem.title: AFGHANISTAN: Afghan Taleban scoff at CIS concerns.
newsitem.headline: Afghan Taleban scoff at CIS concerns.

text.p: Kabul's new purist Islamic rulers scoffed on Saturday at concerns voiced by the Confederation of Independent States (CIS) over their sweep to power over much of Afghanistan.
"I am very happy that God has given this much pomp and credit to the Taleban that a big power is afraid of the Taleban," acting information minister Amir Jan Mutaqi told a news conference.

Five leaders of former Soviet republics, alarmed by the rise of the Taleban, ended a summit in Almaty on Friday with an appeal to the rival groups to hold talks and for the United Nations to discuss the situation.
"We call upon all warring parties to stop hostilities and resume peace negotiations," Kazakh President Nursultan Nazarbayev had said in a joint news conference.
The Almaty summit was attended by the presidents of Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan, and by Russian Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin.
It was called to discuss possible steps if the Taleban were to advance north to the southern borders of the CIS, a loose 12-member grouping formed as the Soviet Union collapsed in 1991.
"Russia has no more the talent or the capacity in this kind of action. (Russian President Boris) Yeltsin is himself sick and is not able to do anything," Mutaqi said.
"The Russian people have not forgotten their past experience in Afghanistan and I think they won't dare to repeat that," he said.
The CIS had criticised the "executions and human rights violations" being committed in the war-ravaged nation.

Among those killed when the Taleban seized Kabul last month was former Moscow-backed Afghan president Najibullah, a communist installed as leader in 1987 during the 10-year Soviet occupation of the country.
